Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Efficient nanowire based gas sensor
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a sensor platform that can monitor the presence of toxic gases in the environment. The device is intended for a wide range of applications ranging from its use in the oil and gas industry to its use as breath analyzers with applications in law and order as well as in health related fields. The proposed nanoscale device will result in relatively cheap and reliable gas sensors that can be used around gas extraction sites to monitor extremely small concentrations of toxic gases like sulphur dioxide, methane, carbon-monoxide, ammonia and hydrogen. They can also be mounted in select areas in schools and hospitals. Medical personnel could use the sensor to test the quality of exhaled air to detect high levels of nitric oxide (high levels indicative of asthma), sulfur (high levels indicative of liver dysfunction) and acetone (high levels in diabetic patients).

This I-Corps project proposes to use one-dimensional nanowires as sensing elements, working on the principle that the nanowire resistance changes as its surface is modified by adsorbed gas molecules. With lengths of several tens of microns and diameters in the range of nanometers, nanowires have large surface-to-volume ratio. Hence a large number of surface sites will be available on each nanowire to facilitate surface reactions with the adsorbed gas molecules. The project is based on successful experiments where significant changes in the electrical conductance of individual nanowires were measured within several seconds of exposure to gases like ammonia, methanol, chlorine, hydrogen, and sulfur. The sensing mechanism is dominated by changes in the nanowire channel conductance caused by a change in the energy band structure when gas molecules are adsorbed on the nanowire surface. The nanoscale sensors are expected to be highly sensitive, with faster responses and can operate at room temperature, requiring low operating power. To increase gas selectivity, additional features can be added to the nanowire surface. Arrays of such nanowires mounted on a single chip will result in a highly versatile device that can be used for monitoring and sensing toxic gases in our immediate environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 'gas sensor' team successfully completed the I-Corps program and have formulated a well investigated strategy to tap into the gas sensor market for monitoring air quality. The team conducted over 120 interviews, the Principal Investigator gave 4 talks and 3 scientists visited our nanoscale lab at UNT to discuss feasibility of collaborating and using the nanoscale sensing technology for environment monitoring in semiconductor industries and oil and gas fields. Due to stringent security measures, it was extremely hard for the team to get face-to-face interviews with oil/gas industry personnel in the United States.  For insights into the needs of this industry, the PI and the entrepreneurial lead (EL) visited India where they used their contacts and friends in the region to arrange for interviews with site engineers and technicians in the oil/gas fields as well as company CEO. This allowed for meaningful discussions on the current market needs and how best to navigate the marketing process including pricing and profit margins. Through the attendance at the trade show in Bangalore in India, it was possible to meet several leading entrepreneurs and learn about breakthrough technologies that enable a cleaner environment.   The technologies included techniques for controlling air and water pollution, setting up of novel bio-gas plants and organic waste converter machines for generating electricity. The team was also able to engage in a discussion with the founder of a private company in India that markets gas sensors all over the Indian sub-continent. The sensing device in this case was made in China and sold relatively cheap to OEMs (original equipment manufacturers), who then adapts them based on intended use. 

The graduate student who served as the EL acquired communication and entrepreneurial skills as he navigated through some very tough interviews. He also benefited from the workshops and the weekly presentations by the teaching team. The major outcome of this work is the market survey by the team and fabrication of the nanowires as sensing elements. The sensor works on the principle that the nanowire resistance changes as its surface is modified by adsorbed gas molecules. Since nanowires are produced by relatively inexpensive methods, the sensor cost is very low. The team is now at the stage where it intends to make the transition from being innovation-driven to being market-focused by effectively linking the research and marketing efforts. Going forward the team will benefit from the experience and industry contacts of our team mentor. The team will be working with an OEM to incorporate the sensor into a wearable sensing device at competitive pricing. 

The team has successfully lab-tested the nanowire sensor and it has shown high sensitivity to several gases in the controlled lab environment where the sensitivity has been determined for a single gas at any given time. These results were discussed with potential customers. The next step is to introduce a gas mixture onto a device consisting of several sensing windows, each with an array comprising of several nanowires and determining if the individual array can accurately detect the presence of the gas in the mixture that it was calibrated to detect. We have also had discussion with researchers at the Gas Technology Institute in Chicago and the Downwinders group in Texas to field-test our sensing device in a real-life environment where temperature, humidity, dust particulates and the general ambience can negatively impact sensor performance. In addition to sensitivity, it is also important to ensure reliability and fast response. 

The team is confident that an efficient nanoscale gas sensor will allow for cheap and ubiquitous sensing which will be a huge benefit to residents who live close to fracking or drilling sites or those who live downwind to big industries. The possibility that these nanoscale sensors can be integrated into popular consumer products like smart watches, cell phones or GPS will benefit industrial workers since this would be a wearable sensor that can detect toxic gases in the environment before it can endanger lives.
